channel.title: How To Setup / Use Eclipse For Your Server
channel.description:
[center][b]I DID NOT WRITE THIS ALL CREDITS TO Purple From R-S[/b][/center]
Vault requested it. Other people might find it useful. [center]*Adding The Download Link - http://www.eclipse.org/downloads/ (Pick which one you need Usually It will be Eclipse IDE for Java Developers If your just starting then select your system type and download.[/center] 1. Open eclipse (duh)
2.[img]http://i52.tinypic.com/1zh36ea.png[/img]
3.[img]http://i53.tinypic.com/2jfhypu.png[/img]
4. Tick off the 'Use default location' box.
[img]http://i56.tinypic.com/23ht3q9.png[/img]
Then press 'Finish'.
Now you have imported the server in to Eclipse, if you want to run the server through Eclipse, keep following this. If not, you can just change page.
5. Press the green play button.
[img]http://i52.tinypic.com/27yvgox.png[/img]
6. Select 'Java Application'
[img]http://i55.tinypic.com/117uydk.png[/img]
7. Select the class that will run the server. (Usually it's server.)
[img]http://i54.tinypic.com/24q0kyq.png[/img] Press Ok after.
Picture of server running correctly: [img]http://i55.tinypic.com/30dgwud.png[/img]
And you are done
Useful information:
Eclipse uses an auto-compiler, which means it will compile right after you edit + save a file. You can disable it by going in to Project->Build Automatically, and you can compile through Project->Build Project or Build All.
[b]Quote From killerj012 on R-S -[/b] Eclipse is a very helpful program. You can easily file search specific files/within file. You can open call hierarchies of various codes and find the origin of any method. You can open the declaration to find out where it's being called from... You can automatically compile. You can view real-time debugging while hosting your server. It helps you with conventions and tells you when there's a bug in your code and how to fix it. This is about 2% of what you can do with Eclipse....

item.title: How To Setup / Use Eclipse For Your Server
item.dc:creator: @Crown2 Crown2

thats what it says in the original thread and i dident change it

Read full topic

item.title: How To Setup / Use Eclipse For Your Server
item.dc:creator: @Crown2 Crown2
item.description:
@Crown2 wrote:

[center]I DID NOT WRITE THIS ALL CREDITS TO Purple From R-S[/center]

Vault requested it. Other people might find it useful.
[center]*Adding The Download Link - http://www.eclipse.org/downloads/ (Pick which one you need Usually It will be Eclipse IDE for Java Developers If your just starting then select your system type and download.[/center]

  1. Open eclipse (duh)

2.

1zh36ea.png1366×728

3.

2jfhypu.png555×531

  1. Tick off the ‘Use default location’ box.

23ht3q9.png795×747

Then press ‘Finish’.

Now you have imported the server in to Eclipse, if you want to run the server through Eclipse, keep following this. If not, you can just change page.

  1. Press the green play button.

  1. Select ‘Java Application’

  1. Select the class that will run the server. (Usually it’s server.)

24q0kyq.png630×531

Press Ok after.

Picture of server running correctly:

And you are done

Useful information:

Eclipse uses an auto-compiler, which means it will compile right after you edit + save a file. You can disable it by going in to Project->Build Automatically, and you can compile through Project->Build Project or Build All.

Quote From killerj012 on R-S -
Eclipse is a very helpful program. You can easily file search specific files/within file. You can open call hierarchies of various codes and find the origin of any method. You can open the declaration to find out where it’s being called from… You can automatically compile. You can view real-time debugging while hosting your server. It helps you with conventions and tells you when there’s a bug in your code and how to fix it. This is about 2% of what you can do with Eclipse…

Read full topic
